The Company or any Telegraph Company or Government Telegraph Administration, by whom this telegram is or would in the ordinary course of the telegraphic service be forwarded, may decline to forward such telegram although it has been received for that purpose ; but in such case the amount paid for transmission will be refunded to the sender at his request. 2. The above mentioned conditions also apply to telegrams tendered to or delivered by the Company by telephone, over a private line, or by any other means whatsoever. NOTE.—Code words used in the text of telegrams must not contain more than 5 letters. The use of accented letters is not permitted in code words. By International Regulations, the sender of a telegram is obliged to produce the code from which the text or part of the text in code has been compiled if requested by the office of origin. If figures and groups of figures, including commercial marks containing figures and letters, are used in code telegrams directed to extra-European destinations, their number, reckoned in accordance with the Rules for charging, must not exceed one half of the number of chargeable words in the text and signature. MB.Ne. 8(7/9/l-A/49) British Consulate, Musc&t• January 30, 1949. In confirmation of our conversation this morning, I have the honour to inform Your Highness that the following time-table has been fixed for the various calls, salutes, and so on, on the occasion of the Commander-in-chief’s visit January 31st. OB.30 HfflS Norfolk arrives and salutes country. Shore battery replies. 09.30 Consul calls on C-in-C Ship fires salute 10.15 C-in-C cones ashore Chore battery salutes. 10.45 C-in-C accompanied by Consul calls on His Highness the Sultan. 11.30 His Highness the Sultan returns call. Ship fires salute. Your Highness sincere friend, His Highness Saiyid Said bin Taimur, Sultan of Afuscat and Oman, reseat •SLOPPY* FOR INFORMATION, TO. ADMIRALTY. INFORMATION TO. BIRMINGHAM R.N.O. NORFOLK intend to proceed on following cruise. Arrive. Place. Blank. COLOMBO 30th December 6th January. BAHRAIN 11th January. 12th January. BASRA 17th January. 17th January. ABADAN 24th January. 25th January. KUWAIT 27th January. 29th January. KHOR KUWAI , 30th January. 31st January. MUSCAT 3rd February. 3. 4. Onward programme will be signalled. S.N.O.P.G. is requested to inform necessary authorities in Persian Gulf. 05 1056 EF.Telegram From M Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, London i To Political Agent, Ifluscat No. 1 Dated and received the 7th January, 1949. British Residency Bahrain, Persian Gulf. > { AP. /<L- ^ 19b .Telegram Interdepartmental Frem Political Agent, Muscat Te Senior Naval Officer, Persian Gulf, Warship Wildgoose, Bahrain Radio No. 11 Dated the 4th January, 1949. ^ • Your telerram January 3rd. Prograrame agreed by Sultan except that he has not yet suggested dinner party at palace. This must be left doubtful. Minor details such as time ®f shooting match can be settled on arrival. Sultana is not repeat not in Tfuscat. ELLISON.Telegram Fr*m Enclair S.N.O.P.G., HMS Wildgeose To Political Agent, Jluscat No. nil Dated the 3rd received the 4th January, 1949. Request confirmation by telegram of tentative programme arranged with you for visit of Commander-in-Chief. SENIOR NAVAL OFFICER PERSIAN GULFVISIT OF HORFOU TO MUSCAT FROM 31st JAM TO 3rd FEE . MONDAY 31st. January. 8*30 a.m. 9.30 a.ra. 10.15 a.m. 10.45 a.m. HMS Norfolk arrives and salutes country (21 guns) Shore Battery reply. P.A. calls on C-in-C (llguns) C-in-Chief returns call . ( salute will be fired as C-in-C passes Fort Mirani ) C-in-C accompanied by P.A. calls on Sultan 11.30 a.m. 12.10 a.m. 1.30 p.m. Sultan returns call on HUB Norfolk ( 21 guns salute when leaving ) Colony's (male) call on C-in-C in wardroom Lunch at Agency ( 20 Officers, younger colony & Miss W ) 4.15 p.m. Hockey match Navy vs Exiles XI TUESDAY 1st. February. 11 a.m. 2. p.m. 4.15 p.m. f 7 p.ra. 7.45/8 p.m. Whole day picnic at Watieh Arab & Indian school children visit ship Hockey Navy vs. Muscat Infantry Cinema show for about 20 Indians. Dinner at Agency.i * • wy.DT^DAY 2nd February. 12*30 p*m* LuncJ? for Sultan with C-in-C at Consulate. 7.30 p.ra. Buffet and Cinema on board • • • « THURSDAY 3rd February.

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: 'File 9/1 A II Visit of Commander-in-Chief to Muscat'

physicalDescription.extent: The file is arranged in chronological order from the rear to the front.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 24, these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: Correspondence and other papers relating to visits by the Commander-in-Chief, East Indies Station, to Muscat. The file covers visits in early 1949 and 1950. The papers deal with matters such as notifying the Sultan of Muscat, the programme of events for the visits, lists of officers aboard visiting ships, appropriate gun salutes, and the expected movements of HM Ships in the Persian Gulf region. Vessels mentioned in the file include HMS Norfolkand HMS Mauritius.Correspondence comes from: the Senior Naval Officer in the Persian Gulf, Bahrain; the Political Agency, Muscat; the Persian Gulf Residency, Bahrain; the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, London; and Basil Woods Ballard, Minister for Foreign Affairs, Muscat.

name.namePart: Royal Navy, Commander-in-Chief, East Indies Station
